paper_name: The Causal Effect of Radical Right Success on Mainstream Parties’ Policy Positions. A Regression Discontinuity Approach
data_description:
The dataset aims to analyze the effect of radical right parties on the policy positions of the mainstream parties. It includes information on political parties belonging to various European countries, including their positions on cultural protectionism and environmental protectionism. Each country has minimum thresholds for voter shares that the political parties need to meet to get into the parliament. Thresholds vary by country, so in this dataset, we used voter shares centered around the threshold. Similarly, whether a party is rightist or leftist can be determined from the rile score. The classification varies from country to country. Parties with rile scores less than the mean rile scores of all the parties in the given county are classified as leftist. 

Variable description:

iso2c: iso2 character country code
edate: election date
party: CMP-code mainstream party
partyname: name of mainstream party
parfam: party family of mainstream party (CMP-coding)
thrs: electoral threshold
thrs_l: electoral threshold (lagged)
er.v.c: radical right party vote share (centered on electoral threshold)
er.v.c_l: radical right party vote share (centered on electoral threshold, lagged)
er.in: radical right parliamentary presence (binary indicator)
er.in_l: radical right parliamentary presence (binary indicator, lagged)
rile.logit: rile score (according to Lowe et al. 2011)
per607: multiculturalism positive (CMP coding)
per608: multiculturalism negative (CMP coding)
multic.logit_fd: cultural protectionism score (Lowe version, first difference)
per608_fd: per608 score (first difference)
multic.ratio_fd: cultural protectionism score (Kim and Fording version, first difference) 
af.bipolar_fd: cultural protectionism score (Alonso and da Fonseca version, first difference) 
meguid.bipolar_fd: cultural protectionism score (Meguid 2008 version, first difference) 
env.logit_fd: environment protection score (Lowe version, first difference)
natural_language_query: How much does earmarked funding affect the performance of international organisations?
control_variables: iso2c
remark: This needs preprocessing. First, need to determine whether a party is right or left wing from the rile scores. Then, select only leftist parties.

paper_name: Does earmarked funding affect the performance of international organisations?
data_description:
The dataset compiles performance evaluations of 32 international organizations (IOs) from 2009 to 2021, encompassing 64 assessments conducted by the Multilateral Organization Performance Assessment Network (MOPAN). Organizations vary significantly in their funding composition, with some receiving predominantly core contributions that provide operational flexibility, while others rely heavily on earmarked resources that restrict fund usage to specific purposes, sectors, or geographic areas. Due to their specific nature, earmarked funding does not offer felexibility. Thus, there is a possiblility that earmarked funding may limit organizational performances. The dataset tracks both short-term and long-term earmarked funding patterns alongside core funding levels. International organizations' performance is given by two metrics: 1) Process performance, the extent to which organizations have rules to plan and manage operations strategically, and 2) outcome performance, which measures the organization's success in achieving desired results. 


Variables:
organization: international organization name
acronym: organization abbreviation
year: assessment year
mopan: The version of MOPAN methodology used in the assessment (one of 3.0, 3.1, or 3.0*, CA = older version)
newmopan: Binary variable that is 1 if the new MOPAN assessment methodology was used. 
y1: process performance factor score
y2: outcome performance factor score
y1n: process performance factor score after removing 2 micro indicators 
y2n: outcome performance factor score after removing 2 micro indicators 
EMST: earmarked funding share in the year before MOPAN assessment (t-1 year) 
EMLT: earmarked funding share in the years t-2 and t-3 before MOPAN assessment i.e., 2 and 3 years before
un: indicator for UN system organizations (1 = UN organization, 0 = non-UN organization)
coreSTd: non-core funding amount 
coreST: core funding amount
emST: earmarked funding amount 
emST_MBI: earmarked funding amount computed by MOPAN
emshareLTd: Share of earmarked funding in the IO budget based on data from UN DESA Data
emshareLTb: Share of earmarked funding in the IO budget based on data from UN Data Cube
emshareLT: Share earmarked funding share for long-term projects 
nproj_lt: number of earmarked projects 
ndon_lt: number of donors providing earmarked funding 
states_num: number of member states
states_unga_sd: standard deviation of the preferences of the member states with respect to ideal point estimates 
tenure: executive head tenure length
selectorate:  Variable indicating how the executive is selected (1= appointed by the chief of parent organization, 2=selected by the board, 3 = chosen by  the assembly of member states)
founding: organization founding year
hq: headquarters location
field_presence: number of staff in the field 
staff_count: total staff size
normio: indicator for norm-making IOs: FAO, ILO, UNESCO, UNHCR, UNIDO, WHO, GEF
lnsectors: logarithm of the number of sectors in which the organization receives donor funding 
meanwSIM: weighted mean cosine similarity of sector-specific contribution profile, which is proportional to the total budget of the IOs
natural_language_query: How much does earmarked funding share in the preceeding year affect the process performance of international organisations?
control_variables: newmopan

paper_name: Cabinets, Committees, and Careers: The Causal Effect of Committee Service
data_description:
The dataset comes from French parliamentary records across multiple legislative sessions. It is structured by deputy-year, and includes variables for legislative behavior, career success, policy-making, tenure, and constituent characteristics. An interesting feature of the lower house was that the legislature was randomly assigned into 11 groups called bureaux, and each group chose members to serve on the budget committee. The deputies convened with their assigned group, and after hours of discussion, each bureau nominated three representatives to serve on the budget committee. Bureaux was a temporary committee, and the selection was done every year. This random selection of bureaux (or bureau) for budget selection was done from 1894 to 1910, after which it was disbanded. 


Variable description:

id: ID number (Unique identifier for each deputy)
year: Year (1894-1909)
term: Term (1893, 1898, 1902, or 1906)
leader: Deputy was any type of party leader (defined as a member of a parliamentary governing committee) (1=yes, 0 = no)
centrist_all: Deputy was a member of a Radical or Radical-Socialist party (1- Radical socialist, 0=radical party)
inscrits: Number of electors in deputy’s district (in 000s)
permargin: Electoral margin of prior election, as a ratio of total votes cast
paris: Whether the deputy represents a Parisian district or suburb (1=Parisian district, 0 = suburb)
age: Age of deputy
bureau: Deputy’s bureau number (assignment) for that year
budget: Deputy was on the budget committee (1=yes, 0=no)
min: Deputy was a minister  (1=yes, 0 = np)
termyear: Identifier for term + year
budgettermyears: Number of years a deputy has served on the budget committee, including the current year
budgetexptermyears: Budget experience in years
proprietaire: Deputy was a property owner (upper class)  (1=yes, 0=no)
lib_all: Deputy held a liberal profession (middle class)  ((1=yes, 0=no)
civil: Deputy was a civil servant  (1=yes, 0=no)
reelect: Deputy was reelected the next term  (1=yes, 0=no)
F1to5firstminyear: Became a minister for the first time within 5 years (1=yes, 0=no)
F1to5firstleaderyear: Became a party leader within 5 years (1=yes, 0=no)
cummyears: Years of parliamentary experience
clburyear: Identifier for term year + bureau
budgetincumbent: Deputy was a budget incumbent (1=yes, 0=no)
bureauotherbudgetincumbent: Number of budget incumbents in deputy’s bureau (excluding deputy)
reelectterm: Deputy was reelected the next term (1=yes, 0=no)
reelecttwoterm: Deputy was reelected within the next two terms (1=yes, 0=no)
senate: Deputy was a senator  (1=yes, 0=no)
rannext: Deputy ran for reelection in the subsequent term (1=yes, 0=no)
F1to5senateyear: Became a senator within 5 years (1=yes, 0=no)
F1to5billdummy: Sponsored a bill within 5 years (1=yes, 0=no)
F1to5billfinancedummy: Sponsored a finance bill within 5 years (1=yes, 0=no)
F1to5billecondummy: Sponsored an econ bill within 5 years (1=yes, 0=no)
F1to5billwelfaredummy: Sponsored a welfare bill within 5 years (1=yes, 0=no)
F1to5billbudgetdummy: Sponsored a budget bill within 5 years (1=yes, 0=no)
F1to5billagendadummy: Sponsored an agenda bill within 5 years (1=yes, 0=no)
F1to5billinterpdummy: Sponsored an interpellation bill within 5 years (1=yes, 0=no)
F1to5cosponsordummy: Cosponsored a budget bill within 5 years (1=yes, 0=no)
F1to5cosponsordummy_anybm: Co-sponsored with current or previous budget committee member within 5 years (1=yes, 0=no)
cummyears2: Years of parliamentary experience squared
age2: Age, squared
inscrits2: Electors, squared
permargin2: Electoral Margin of Prior Election, squared 
deptcode: Department ID
natural_language_query: Does a deputy being on the budget committee increase the likelihood of sponsoring a budget bill?
control_variables: age, age2, inscrits, inscrits2, permargin, permargin2, cummyears, cummyears2, proprietaire, lib_all, civil, paris, budgetincumbent, year

paper_name: Improving Balance in Regression Discontinuity Design by Matching: Estimating the Effect of Academic Probation after the First Year of College
data_description:
This dataset comprises comprehensive academic records from a large Canadian university system, consisting of one central campus and two smaller satellite campuses. The data tracks 12,530 first-year students who entered the university between the 1996-97 and 2003-04 academic years, with students aged 17-21 at entry. The dataset focuses on students whose academic performance places them near institutional academic standing thresholds, specifically those with first-year GPAs within a range of the university's academic evaluation criteria. Different campuses maintain distinct GPA cutoffs for academic standing assessments, resulting in variations in institutional policies across the university system. Students are placed on academic probation if their GPA falls below the cutoffs. The longitudinal structure captures academic performance across multiple terms and years, including semester and cumulative GPAs, total credits attempted and completed, registration patterns for fall and summer terms, and academic standing determinations. Outcome measures track graduation status at 4, 5, and 6-year intervals, along with probation and suspension incidents.

Variable description:

winter_ac_standing: winter academic standing status (OKAY or PROB (indicating probation))
GPA_year1: grade point average by academic year 1
GPA_year2: grade point average for academic year 2
CGPA_year1: cumulative grade point average for year 1
CGPA_year2: cumulative grade point average for year 2
totcredits_year1: total academic credits attempted in year 1
totcredits_year2: total academic credits attempted in year 2
winter_ac_stand_year1: winter academic standing status in year 1 (OKAY or PROB (indicating probation))
winter_ac_stand_year2: winter academic standing status in year 2 (OKAY or PROB (indicating probation))
goodstanding_year1: binary representation of winter_ac_stand_year1; Indicator for academic standing (1 = OKAY, 0= PROB)
goodstanding_year2: binary representation of winter_ac_stand_year2; Indicator for academic standing (1 = OKAY, 0= PROB)
fallreg_year1: fall term registration status in year 2(1 = registered, 0 = not registered)
fallreg_year2: fall term registration status in year 2(1 = registered, 0 = not registered)
summerreg_year1: summer term registration status in year 1
summerreg_year2: summer term registration status in year 1
sex: Sex of the student (MALE / FEMALE)
female: 1 = FEMALE, 0 = otherwise 
male: 1 = MALE, 0 = otherwise 
mtongue: mother tongue language
age_at_entry: student age at university entry
bpl_north_america, bpl_asia, bpl_other: Binary variables to indicate birth place regions (1 = born in that region, 0 = not born in that region)
canadian: Canadian citizenship status (1 = yes, 0=no)
firstyear: year the student first entered the university 
yearstodegree: time taken to complete the degree
gradin4, gradin5, gradin6: Binary variables that indicate if the student graduated within the specified years 
cumcredits1, cumcredits2: cumulative credits completed in years 1 and 2 
prog_science/prog_socsci_bus/prog_socscihum: binary variable that indicates the academic program of the student: science, social science, humanities 
english, french, other_lang: binary variable indicating whether the student's main language is English, French, or some other language  
gpacutoff: GPA evaluation threshold
dist_from_cut: distance from academic threshold
probation_year1: probation status by year 1
probation_year2: probation status by year 2
suspended_year1: suspension status by year 1
suspended_year2: suspension status by year 2
loc_campus1, loc_campus2, loc_campus3: Binary indicators for campus location 
hsgrade_pct: high school grade percentile
veryhighHS, highHS, lowHS: Binary indicators for high school performance in high school 
hsgrade_pct: overall percentage achieved in high school 
left_school: binary variable representing whether the student left school (1) or not (0)
natural_language_query: Are students placed on academic probation after their first year likely to leave their studies at the university?

paper_name: Deep IV: A Flexible Approach for Counterfactual Prediction
data_description:
This dataset contains simulated consumer behavior data examining relationships between pricing decisions and market demand across various emotional and temporal contexts. The data structure reflects a complex economic environment where pricing strategies may be influenced by factors that also affect consumer demand. Pricing information is represented through both continuous normalized measures and categorical indicators distinguishing between different price levels. The data captures market demand responses across various pricing scenarios, with additional variables tracking price positioning within broader market distributions.

Variable description:
obs_id: unique observation identifier
seed: randomization seed for simulation
treatment_price_normalized: standardized pricing measure
outcome_demand: consumer demand response
instrument_z: auxiliary variable for pricing analysis
temporal_time: time measurement
state_emotion_id: emotional state category identifier; takes values 0, 1, 2, .. 6. 
covariate_emotion_0 to covariate_emotion_6: emotional state indicators across seven categories
unobserved_confounder_v: unmeasured factor affecting pricing and demand
price_percentile: pricing position within market distribution
treatment_high_price: indicator for high pricing condition
treatment_low_price: indicator for low pricing condition
instrument_strong: strength indicator for auxiliary pricing variable
time_category: categorical time period
counterfactual_demand_low_price: hypothetical demand under low pricing
counterfactual_demand_high_price: hypothetical demand under high pricing
individual_treatment_effect: person-specific response to pricing changes
natural_language_query: How does increase in product cost affect customer demand?
control_variables: time, emotion_0, covariate_emotion_0, covariate_emotion_1, covariate_emotion_2, covariate_emotion_3, covariate_emotion_4, covariate_emotion_5, covariate_emotion_6, temporal_time
remark: This is a synthetic data with known effects.

paper_name: Do Politicians Racially Discriminate Against Constituents? A Field Experiment on State Legislators
data_description:
This study utilizes randomized field experiments to examine the interactions between constituents and state legislators across the United States during October 2008. Legislators across multiple states were sent an email asking for help with the voter registration process for the primary election using black (DeShawn Jackson) or white alias names (Jake Mueller). The sender name, the legislature receiving the email, and the (hypothetical) party affiliation of the sender were randomly assigned. Not all letters included information on which political party's primary election the sender was interested in. Legislative offices were contacted through official email addresses posted on state government websites. The outcome of interest is whether the legislator responded by the November election date or not.


Variable Descriptions:
leg_party: Political party affiliation of the state legislator (R = Republican, D= Democrat)
leg_republican: Binary indicator for legislators affiliated with the Republican Party
leg_black: Binary indicator for legislators who identify as Black or African American
leg_latino: Binary indicator for legislators who identify as Latino or Hispanic
leg_white: Binary indicator for legislators who identify as white
leg_notwhite: Binary indicator for legislators who identify as non-white
leg_notblackotherminority: Binary indicator for legislators who identify as minorities other than Black (including Latino, Asian American, Native American, and Arab American legislators)
reply_atall: Binary indicator for whether the legislative office provided any form of response to the constituent inquiry
treat_deshawn: Binary indicator for communications associated with the name "DeShawn Jackson"
treat_jake: Binary indicator for communications associated with the name "Jake Mueller"
treat_group: Categorical variable indicating the specific combination of communication characteristics
treat_demprimary: Binary indicator for communications that mentioned interest in Democratic primary elections
treat_repprimary: Binary indicator for communications that mentioned interest in Republican primary elections
treat_noprimary: Binary indicator for communications that did not specify any particular primary election interest
treat_primary: Binary indicator for communications that included any reference to primary election participation (either Democratic or Republican)
natural_language_query: Do legislators respond more often to black alias names when no partisan signal is included in the email?
control_variables: leg_republican, leg_black, leg_latino, leg_white, leg_notwhite, leg_notblackotherminority

paper_name: Community and the Crime Decline: The Causal Effect of Local Nonprofits on Violent Crime
data_description:
This study examines community organizations and public safety patterns across major US cities during a period of significant social change from 1990 to 2013. The dataset encompasses comprehensive information on 264 of the largest cities in the United States, capturing various aspects of urban life, including organizational presence, demographic characteristics, economic conditions, and public safety indicators. The analysis draws on multiple data sources, including the FBI's Uniform Crime Reports, the National Center for Charitable Statistics, and US Census data. The dataset represents one of the most comprehensive longitudinal examinations of urban organizational infrastructure and community safety patterns during a critical period in American urban development. Cities range from major metropolitan centers to smaller urban areas, providing broad geographic and demographic representation across all major US regions during the 1990s to 2010s period.

Variable Descriptions

poprank: Population-based ranking of cities within the national urban hierarchy
agency: Law enforcement agency responsible for crime reporting in each jurisdiction
place_name: Official name of the municipal entity
place_id: Unique numerical identifier for each city
place_id_str: String version of the unique place identifier
state_ab: Two-letter state postal abbreviation
state_id: Numerical state identifier
state_name: Full state name
region: Census region classification code
region_str: Census region name designation
division: US Census Bureau division classification
year: Calendar year of observation (1990-2013)
year_str: Year designation in string format
years_crime: Total number of years for which crime data is available for each city
first_crime: Earliest year of available crime data
last_crime: Most recent year of available crime data
y_1990 through y_2012: Binary indicators for each individual year in the dataset
year_region: Combined year and region identifier
year_region_num: Numerical encoding of year-region combinations
year_reg_1 through year_reg_120: Individual year-region interaction indicators
totpop: Total resident population count
pop2010: Population count as recorded in the 2010 Census
pop1990: Population count as recorded in the 1990 Census
pop2000: Population count as recorded in the 2000 Census
popweights: Statistical weights based on population size
area: Overall geographic area of the municipal boundary
popdens: Population density per square unit of area
logpop: Natural logarithm of the 1990 population
logpopdens: Natural logarithm of population density
largest50: Binary indicator for cities ranking among the 50 most populous in the US
largest100: Binary indicator for cities ranking among the 100 most populous in the US
viol: Absolute count of violent crimes reported annually
viol_r: Violent crime rate per 100,000 residents
murd: Absolute count of homicides reported annually
murd_r: Murder rate per 100,000 residents
rape: Absolute count of reported sexual assaults
rape_r: Sexual assault rate per 100,000 residents
robbery: Absolute count of reported robberies
robbery_r: Robbery rate per 100,000 residents
assault: Absolute count of reported aggravated assaults
assault_r: Aggravated assault rate per 100,000 residents
prop: Absolute count of property crimes reported annually
prop_r: Property crime rate per 100,000 residents
burglary: Absolute count of reported burglaries
burglary_r: Burglary rate per 100,000 residents
larceny: Absolute count of reported larceny-theft incidents
larceny_r: Larceny-theft rate per 100,000 residents
autotheft: Absolute count of reported motor vehicle thefts
autotheft_r: Motor vehicle theft rate per 100,000 residents
community_new: Count of newly established community-focused nonprofit organizations
community_cml: Cumulative count of active community-focused nonprofit organizations
crime_new: Count of newly established crime prevention organizations
crime_cml: Cumulative count of active crime prevention organizations
housing_new: Count of newly established housing-related organizations
housing_cml: Cumulative count of active housing-related organizations
jobs_new: Count of newly established workforce development organizations
jobs_cml: Cumulative count of active workforce development organizations
nhood_new: Count of newly established neighborhood development organizations
nhood_cml: Cumulative count of active neighborhood development organizations
reentry_new: Count of newly established prisoner reentry support organizations
reentry_cml: Cumulative count of active prisoner reentry support organizations
substance_new: Count of newly established substance abuse prevention organizations
substance_cml: Cumulative count of active substance abuse prevention organizations
youth_new: Count of newly established youth-related organizations
youth_cml: Cumulative count of active youth-related organizations
Various _r suffixed variables: Rate calculations expressing organizational counts per 100,000 residents (for example, substance_cml_r represents the cumulative count of substance-abuse prevention organizations per 100000 residents)
all_new_r: Rate of all newly established nonprofits per 100,000 residents
all_cml_r: Rate of all cumulative active nonprofits per 100,000 residents
white: Percentage of residents identifying as white (non-Hispanic)
black: Percentage of residents identifying as Black or African American
asian: Percentage of residents identifying as Asian
hispanic: Percentage of residents identifying as Hispanic or Latino
other: Percentage of residents identifying with other racial/ethnic categories
fborn: Percentage of foreign-born residents
male1524: Percentage of male residents aged 15 to 24 years
female1524: Percentage of female residents aged 15 to 24 years
lesshs: Percentage of residents 25 years and older without a high school diploma
college: Percentage of residents 25 years and older with a bachelor's degree or higher
hsdropout: High school dropout rate
unemployed: Overall unemployment rate
unemployed_male: Male-specific unemployment rate
unemployed_female: Female-specific unemployment rate
notlabforce: Percentage of residents not participating in the labor force
notlabforce_male: Percentage of males not participating in the labor force
notlabforce_female: Percentage of females not participating in the labor force
manufacturing: Percentage of employed residents working in manufacturing industries
poverty: Percentage of residents living below the federal poverty line
vacancy: Housing vacancy rate
incarceration: Incarceration Rate 
log_incarceration: Natural logarithm of incarceration rate
swornftime_r: Number of sworn police officers per capita 
iv_cml: Cumulative number of new non-profits focusing on the arts, medical research, and environmental protectionism 
iv_cml_r: Cumulative number of new non-profits focusing on the arts, medical research, and environmental protectionism per 100000 residents 
log_viol_r: Natural logarithm of violent crime rate
log_prop_r: Natural logarithm of property crime rate
log_murd_r: Natural logarithm of murder rate
Multiple lagged difference variables (log_viol_r_1ld through log_viol_r_5ld): Historical differences in log violent crime rates over 1-5 year periods
Multiple lagged growth variables (log_viol_r_1lg through log_viol_r_5lg): Historical growth patterns in log violent crime rates over 1-5 year periods
Similar lagged difference and growth variables for property crime (log_prop_r_Xld/lg) and murder rates (log_murd_r_Xld/lg)
natural_language_query: Does local nonprofit communities have a causal effect on the logarithm of violent crime rates?
control_variables: popdens, asian, black, hispanic, other, lesshs, college, fborn, male1524, poverty, unemployed, manufacturing

place_id_str: String version of the unique place identifier
state_ab: Two-letter state postal abbreviation
state_id: Numerical state identifier
state_name: Full state name
region: Census region classification code
region_str: Census region name designation
division: US Census Bureau division classification
year: Calendar year of observation (1990-2013)
year_str: Year designation in string format
years_crime: Total number of years for which crime data is available for each city
first_crime: Earliest year of available crime data
last_crime: Most recent year of available crime data
y_1990 through y_2012: Binary indicators for each individual year in the dataset
year_region: Combined year and region identifier
year_region_num: Numerical encoding of year-region combinations
year_reg_1 through year_reg_120: Individual year-region interaction indicators
totpop: Total resident population count
pop2010: Population count as recorded in the 2010 Census
pop1990: Population count as recorded in the 1990 Census
pop2000: Population count as recorded in the 2000 Census
popweights: Statistical weights based on population size
area: Overall geographic area of the municipal boundary
popdens: Population density per square unit of area
logpop: Natural logarithm of the 1990 population
logpopdens: Natural logarithm of population density
largest50: Binary indicator for cities ranking among the 50 most populous in the US
largest100: Binary indicator for cities ranking among the 100 most populous in the US
viol: Absolute count of violent crimes reported annually
viol_r: Violent crime rate per 100,000 residents
murd: Absolute count of homicides reported annually
murd_r: Murder rate per 100,000 residents
rape: Absolute count of reported sexual assaults
rape_r: Sexual assault rate per 100,000 residents
robbery: Absolute count of reported robberies
robbery_r: Robbery rate per 100,000 residents
assault: Absolute count of reported aggravated assaults
assault_r: Aggravated assault rate per 100,000 residents
prop: Absolute count of property crimes reported annually
prop_r: Property crime rate per 100,000 residents
burglary: Absolute count of reported burglaries
burglary_r: Burglary rate per 100,000 residents
larceny: Absolute count of reported larceny-theft incidents
larceny_r: Larceny-theft rate per 100,000 residents
autotheft: Absolute count of reported motor vehicle thefts
autotheft_r: Motor vehicle theft rate per 100,000 residents
community_new: Count of newly established community-focused nonprofit organizations
community_cml: Cumulative count of active community-focused nonprofit organizations
crime_new: Count of newly established crime prevention organizations
crime_cml: Cumulative count of active crime prevention organizations
housing_new: Count of newly established housing-related organizations
housing_cml: Cumulative count of active housing-related organizations
jobs_new: Count of newly established workforce development organizations
jobs_cml: Cumulative count of active workforce development organizations
nhood_new: Count of newly established neighborhood development organizations
nhood_cml: Cumulative count of active neighborhood development organizations
reentry_new: Count of newly established prisoner reentry support organizations
reentry_cml: Cumulative count of active prisoner reentry support organizations
substance_new: Count of newly established substance abuse prevention organizations
substance_cml: Cumulative count of active substance abuse prevention organizations
youth_new: Count of newly established youth-related organizations
youth_cml: Cumulative count of active youth-related organizations
Various _r suffixed variables: Rate calculations expressing organizational counts per 100,000 residents (for example, substance_cml_r represents the cumulative count of substance-abuse prevention organizations per 100000 residents)
all_new_r: Rate of all newly established nonprofits per 100,000 residents
all_cml_r: Rate of all cumulative active nonprofits per 100,000 residents
white: Percentage of residents identifying as white (non-Hispanic)
black: Percentage of residents identifying as Black or African American
asian: Percentage of residents identifying as Asian
hispanic: Percentage of residents identifying as Hispanic or Latino
other: Percentage of residents identifying with other racial/ethnic categories
fborn: Percentage of foreign-born residents
male1524: Percentage of male residents aged 15 to 24 years
female1524: Percentage of female residents aged 15 to 24 years
lesshs: Percentage of residents 25 years and older without a high school diploma
college: Percentage of residents 25 years and older with a bachelor's degree or higher
hsdropout: High school dropout rate
unemployed: Overall unemployment rate
unemployed_male: Male-specific unemployment rate
unemployed_female: Female-specific unemployment rate
notlabforce: Percentage of residents not participating in the labor force
notlabforce_male: Percentage of males not participating in the labor force
notlabforce_female: Percentage of females not participating in the labor force
manufacturing: Percentage of employed residents working in manufacturing industries
poverty: Percentage of residents living below the federal poverty line
vacancy: Housing vacancy rate
incarceration: Incarceration Rate 
log_incarceration: Natural logarithm of incarceration rate
swornftime_r: Number of sworn police officers per capita 
iv_cml: Cumulative number of new non-profits focusing on the arts, medical research, and environmental protectionism 
iv_cml_r: Cumulative number of new non-profits focusing on the arts, medical research, and environmental protectionism per 100000 residents 
log_viol_r: Natural logarithm of violent crime rate
log_prop_r: Natural logarithm of property crime rate
log_murd_r: Natural logarithm of murder rate
Multiple lagged difference variables (log_viol_r_1ld through log_viol_r_5ld): Historical differences in log violent crime rates over 1-5 year periods
Multiple lagged growth variables (log_viol_r_1lg through log_viol_r_5lg): Historical growth patterns in log violent crime rates over 1-5 year periods
Similar lagged difference and growth variables for property crime (log_prop_r_Xld/lg) and murder rates (log_murd_r_Xld/lg)
natural_language_query: Do local non-profits help reduce property crime rates (log)?
control_variables: popdens, asian, black, hispanic, other, lesshs, college, fborn, male1524, poverty, unemployed, manufacturing

paper_name: Community and the Crime Decline: The Causal Effect of Local Nonprofits on Violent Crime
data_description:
This study examines community organizations and public safety patterns across major US cities during a period of significant social change from 1990 to 2013. The dataset encompasses comprehensive information on 264 of the largest cities in the United States, capturing various aspects of urban life, including organizational presence, demographic characteristics, economic conditions, and public safety indicators. The analysis draws on multiple data sources, including the FBI's Uniform Crime Reports, the National Center for Charitable Statistics, and US Census data. The dataset represents one of the most comprehensive longitudinal examinations of urban organizational infrastructure and community safety patterns during a critical period in American urban development. Cities range from major metropolitan centers to smaller urban areas, providing broad geographic and demographic representation across all major US regions during the 1990s to 2010s period.

Variable Descriptions

poprank: Population-based ranking of cities within the national urban hierarchy
agency: Law enforcement agency responsible for crime reporting in each jurisdiction
place_name: Official name of the municipal entity
place_id: Unique numerical identifier for each city
place_id_str: String version of the unique place identifier

last_crime: Most recent year of available crime data

paper_name: The Minimum Legal Drinking Age and Crime
data_description:
This dataset contains comprehensive arrest and criminal justice records from California covering individuals around their 21st birthday. The data captures detailed information on various types of criminal offenses, demographic characteristics, and temporal variables that enable analysis of crime patterns across different age groups. The dataset includes both raw count data and population-adjusted rates for multiple categories of criminal activity, spanning from serious felonies to minor infractions and regulatory violations.

Variable Descriptions:

days_to_21: Number of days until or since an individual's 21st birthday
years_to_21: Years until or since turning 21
all: Total number of arrests across all offense categories
felony: Count of felony-level arrests
misdemeanor: Count of misdemeanor-level arrests
fbi_offense_miss: FBI-classified misdemeanor offenses
violent: Total violent crime arrests
murder: Homicide arrests
manslaughter: Manslaughter arrests
rape: Sexual assault arrests
robbery: Robbery arrests
assault: Total assault arrests
aggravated_assault: Aggravated assault arrests
ot_assault: Other types of assault
property: Total property crime arrests
burglary: Burglary arrests
larceny: Theft arrests
mv_theft: Motor vehicle theft arrests
stolen_prop_buy_rec_poss: Receiving stolen property arrests
vandalism: Property damage arrests
ill_drugs: Total drug-related arrests
cocaine_opio_sale_manuf: Cocaine/opiate sales and manufacturing arrests
mj_sale_manuf: Marijuana sales and manufacturing arrests
dang_non_narc_sale_manuf: Other dangerous drug sales/manufacturing arrests
cocaine_opio_posses: Cocaine/opiate possession arrests
mj_posses: Marijuana possession arrests
dang_non_narc_posses: Other dangerous drug possession arrests
alcohol: Total alcohol-related arrests
drunk_at_risk: Public intoxication arrests
dui: Driving under the influence arrests
liquor_laws: Liquor law violation arrests
drunkeness_pc: Public drunkenness arrests
disorderly_cond: Disorderly conduct arrests
vagrancy: Vagrancy arrests
arson: Arson arrests
forgery_counterfit: Forgery and counterfeiting arrests
fraud: Fraud arrests
embezelment: Embezzlement arrests
weapons: Weapons violations
prostitution: Prostitution arrests
sex_offenses: Sexual offense arrests
bookmaking: Illegal gambling arrests
all_other_gambling: Other gambling violations
aga_family_child: Offenses against family and children
curfew_loitering: Curfew and loitering violations
runaways: Runaway arrests
coded_on_offense: Arrests coded by primary offense
county_ordinance: County ordinance violations
outside_warrent: Out-of-jurisdiction warrant arrests
traffic_violations: Traffic violation arrests
hit_run_reckl_driv: Hit and run/reckless driving arrests
parole_violation: Parole violation arrests
dump_or_litter: Illegal dumping/littering violations
trespass: Trespassing arrests
violate_court_order: Court order violations
failure_to_appear: Failure to appear in court
cont_delinq_minor: Contributing to the delinquency of a minor
not_classified: Unclassified arrests
other_reported: Other reported offenses
pop1, pop2, pop3: Population counts for different demographic groups
pop_day1, pop_day2, pop_day3: Daily population estimates
post: Binary indicator variable that is 1 if age >= 21 i.e., the individual is 21
linear, square, cubic: years_to_21 raised to the power 1, 2, and 3 respectively 
linear_post, square_post, cubic_post: Interaction of linear, square, cubic with post 
birthday_19, birthday_20, birthday_21, birthday_22, birthday_23: Dummy variables for 19th, 20th, 21st, 22nd, and 23rd birthday
birthday_19_1, birthday_20_1, birthday_21_1, birthday_22_1, birthday_23_1: Dummy variables for a day after then 19th, 20th, 21st, 22nd, and 23rd birthday
All variables with _r suffix represent population-adjusted rates corresponding to their count variable counterparts. These include crime-specific rates such as violent_r, property_r, alcohol_r, dui_r, and all_r, among others. The rate variables normalize the raw counts by relevant population denominators.
natural_language_query: How does gaining legal access to alcohol at age 21 affect overall arrest rates?
control_variables: birthday_19, birthday_19_1, birthday_20, birthday_20_1, birthday_21, birthday_21_1, birthday_22, birthday_22_1, birthday_23, birthday_23_1, linear, square, linear_post, square_post

paper_name: The Minimum Legal Drinking Age and Crime
data_description:
This dataset contains comprehensive arrest and criminal justice records from California covering individuals around their 21st birthday. The data captures detailed information on various types of criminal offenses, demographic characteristics, and temporal variables that enable analysis of crime patterns across different age groups. The dataset includes both raw count data and population-adjusted rates for multiple categories of criminal activity, spanning from serious felonies to minor infractions and regulatory violations.

Variable Descriptions:

days_to_21: Number of days until or since an individual's 21st birthday
years_to_21: Years until or since turning 21
all: Total number of arrests across all offense categories
felony: Count of felony-level arrests
misdemeanor: Count of misdemeanor-level arrests
fbi_offense_miss: FBI-classified misdemeanor offenses
violent: Total violent crime arrests
murder: Homicide arrests
manslaughter: Manslaughter arrests
rape: Sexual assault arrests
robbery: Robbery arrests
assault: Total assault arrests
aggravated_assault: Aggravated assault arrests
ot_assault: Other types of assault
property: Total property crime arrests
burglary: Burglary arrests
larceny: Theft arrests
mv_theft: Motor vehicle theft arrests
stolen_prop_buy_rec_poss: Receiving stolen property arrests
vandalism: Property damage arrests
ill_drugs: Total drug-related arrests
cocaine_opio_sale_manuf: Cocaine/opiate sales and manufacturing arrests
mj_sale_manuf: Marijuana sales and manufacturing arrests
dang_non_narc_sale_manuf: Other dangerous drug sales/manufacturing arrests
cocaine_opio_posses: Cocaine/opiate possession arrests
mj_posses: Marijuana possession arrests
dang_non_narc_posses: Other dangerous drug possession arrests
alcohol: Total alcohol-related arrests
drunk_at_risk: Public intoxication arrests
dui: Driving under the influence arrests
liquor_laws: Liquor law violation arrests
drunkeness_pc: Public drunkenness arrests
disorderly_cond: Disorderly conduct arrests
vagrancy: Vagrancy arrests
arson: Arson arrests
forgery_counterfit: Forgery and counterfeiting arrests
fraud: Fraud arrests
embezelment: Embezzlement arrests
weapons: Weapons violations
prostitution: Prostitution arrests
sex_offenses: Sexual offense arrests
bookmaking: Illegal gambling arrests
all_other_gambling: Other gambling violations
aga_family_child: Offenses against family and children
curfew_loitering: Curfew and loitering violations
runaways: Runaway arrests
coded_on_offense: Arrests coded by primary offense
county_ordinance: County ordinance violations
outside_warrent: Out-of-jurisdiction warrant arrests
traffic_violations: Traffic violation arrests
hit_run_reckl_driv: Hit and run/reckless driving arrests
parole_violation: Parole violation arrests
dump_or_litter: Illegal dumping/littering violations
trespass: Trespassing arrests
violate_court_order: Court order violations
failure_to_appear: Failure to appear in court
cont_delinq_minor: Contributing to the delinquency of a minor
not_classified: Unclassified arrests
other_reported: Other reported offenses
pop1, pop2, pop3: Population counts for different demographic groups
pop_day1, pop_day2, pop_day3: Daily population estimates
post: Binary indicator variable that is 1 if age >= 21 i.e., the individual is 21
linear, square, cubic: years_to_21 raised to the power 1, 2, and 3 respectively 
linear_post, square_post, cubic_post: Interaction of linear, square, cubic with post 
birthday_19, birthday_20, birthday_21, birthday_22, birthday_23: Dummy variables for 19th, 20th, 21st, 22nd, and 23rd birthday
birthday_19_1, birthday_20_1, birthday_21_1, birthday_22_1, birthday_23_1: Dummy variables for a day after then 19th, 20th, 21st, 22nd, and 23rd birthday
All variables with _r suffix represent population-adjusted rates corresponding to their count variable counterparts. These include crime-specific rates such as violent_r, property_r, alcohol_r, dui_r, and all_r, among others. The rate variables normalize the raw counts by relevant population denominators.
natural_language_query: How does gaining legal access to alcohol at age 21 affect alcohol related crime arrest rates?
control_variables: birthday_19, birthday_19_1, birthday_20, birthday_20_1, birthday_21, birthday_21_1, birthday_22, birthday_22_1, birthday_23, birthday_23_1, linear, square, linear_post, square_post

paper_name: Countering misinformation via WhatsApp: Preliminary evidence from the COVID-19 pandemic in Zimbabwe
data_description:
The data aims to test whether trusted WhatsApp messages can counter COVID-19 misinformation in Zimbabwe. Partnering with Internews and Kubatana, the researchers crafted short weekly messages: Week 1 emphasized transmission and social distancing, Week 2 debunked fake cures. At the WhatsApp broadcast list level, timing was randomized: treatment groups received messages on Monday, control groups on Saturday.
To measure effects, a survey was sent on Thursday. Knowledge was assessed through factual questions, and behavior through a list experiment, where respondents received either a short list (only non-sensitive activities) or a long list (the same activities plus a sensitive one: visiting others during lockdown). Broadcast lists were blocked in groups of four, with random assignment across timing (treatment vs. control) and list length (short vs. long).

Data variables 
ResponseId: identifier for the responses from the individuals
Behavior: number of activities the respondent participated in, coded from 0 to 5
Id: identifier for individuals participating
List: binary variable, equals 1 if the WhatsApp broadcast list is assigned to the long experimental list
qualtrics: binary variable indicating response mode (1 if Qualtrics, 0 if WhatsApp)
T: treatment indicator, equals 1 if the WhatsApp broadcast list is assigned to the treatment group
female: binary variable, equals 1 if the respondent is female
c_Q4: survey question on factual knowledge about COVID-19 transmission or prevention
c_Q5: survey question on factual knowledge about misinformation or fake cures
Knowledge: z-score of the respondent’s answers to the factual questions
c_Q4_1: sub-item of Q4 (first option, coded 1 if correct, 0 otherwise)
c_Q4_3: sub-item of Q4 (third option, coded 1 if correct, 0 otherwise)
c_Q4_4: sub-item of Q4 (fourth option, coded 1 if correct, 0 otherwise)
c_Q4_5: sub-item of Q4 (fifth option, coded 1 if correct, 0 otherwise)
block: randomization block (grouping of broadcast lists created at similar times)
length_subscribe: number of months the WhatsApp broadcast list had been active
Week: indicator for intervention week (1 = distancing message, 2 = misinformation/cures message)
response_rate: fraction of weekly responses coming from WhatsApp per person
Week_id: numeric identifier for the week
urban: binary variable, equals 1 if the individual lived in an urban district
natural_language_query: What is the effect of WhatsApp messages on individuals's knowledge about Covid19?
control_variables: urban, female, qualtrics

paper_name: Voting Made Safe and Easy: The Impact of e-voting on Citizen Perceptions
data_description:
The dataset consists of individual-level responses collected during elections, focusing on voters’ experiences and perceptions of different voting systems, along with contextual details about polling stations and election workers. On election day in Salta, 1,502 voters completed a structured questionnaire: 887 used electronic voting (e-voting), while the remainder voted with paper ballots. A total of 36 polling stations were sampled to reflect comparable socio-economic conditions.
Participants were recruited using gender and age quotas, with the questionnaire tailored to their voting method. Additional information came from election workers and independent observers. The study assessed voter confidence in the process, views on secrecy and transparency, ease and speed of voting, poll worker qualifications, and preferences for electronic versus traditional voting—particularly within Argentina’s split-ticket system. To facilitate interpretation, ordinal responses were recoded into binary indicators distinguishing positive from negative experiences across key outcomes: satisfaction, poll worker competence, ease and speed, candidate selection, confidence in counting, secrecy, and perceived election integrity.

Data variables

polling.place: Polling station (school)
EV: Voting system (1 = electronic voting, 0 = traditional voting)
age.group: Respondent age group
educ: Education level of respondent
male: Gender (1 = male, 0 = female)
tech: Familiarity or comfort with technology; higher values indicate greater familiarity
pol.info: Level of political information; higher values indicate more informed
white.collar: Occupation type (1 = white-collar, 0 = otherwise)
not.full.time: Employment status (1 = not full-time, 0 = full-time)
capable.auth: Poll worker qualification (1 = “quite” or “very qualified,” 0 otherwise)
eval.voting: Overall assessment of voting experience (1 = “very good,” 0 otherwise)
easy.voting: Ease of voting procedure (1 = “very easy,” 0 otherwise)
sure.counted: Confidence that vote was counted accurately (1 = “sure” or “very sure,” 0 otherwise)
conf.secret: Confidence in ballot secrecy (1 = “confident” or “very confident,” 0 otherwise)
how.clean: Perception of election cleanness (1 = “very” or “somewhat clean,” 0 otherwise)
speed: Speed of voting process (1 = “quick” or “very quick,” 0 otherwise)
agree.evoting: Support for substituting traditional voting with e-voting (1 = “agree” or “agree a lot,” 0 otherwise)
eselect.cand: Preference for selecting candidates (1 = electronically, 0 = by hand)
propensity_score: Estimated propensity score for analysis
natural_language_query: Does electronic voting make it easier or harder for people to vote compared to paper ballots?
control_variables: age, age2, age3, educ, educ2, tech, tech2, pol_info, age_x_educ, age_x_tech, educ_x_pol, age_x_pol, tech_x_pol, white.collar, not.full.time, male

agree.evoting: Support for substituting traditional voting with e-voting (1 = “agree” or “agree a lot,” 0 otherwise)

paper_name: Voting Made Safe and Easy: The Impact of e-voting on Citizen Perceptions
data_description:
The dataset consists of individual-level responses collected during elections, focusing on voters’ experiences and perceptions of different voting systems, along with contextual details about polling stations and election workers. On election day in Salta, 1,502 voters completed a structured questionnaire: 887 used electronic voting (e-voting), while the remainder voted with paper ballots. A total of 36 polling stations were sampled to reflect comparable socio-economic conditions.
Participants were recruited using gender and age quotas, with the questionnaire tailored to their voting method. Additional information came from election workers and independent observers. The study assessed voter confidence in the process, views on secrecy and transparency, ease and speed of voting, poll worker qualifications, and preferences for electronic versus traditional voting—particularly within Argentina’s split-ticket system. To facilitate interpretation, ordinal responses were recoded into binary indicators distinguishing positive from negative experiences across key outcomes: satisfaction, poll worker competence, ease and speed, candidate selection, confidence in counting, secrecy, and perceived election integrity.

Data variables

polling.place: Polling station (school)
EV: Voting system (1 = electronic voting, 0 = traditional voting)
age.group: Respondent age group
educ: Education level of respondent
male: Gender (1 = male, 0 = female)
tech: Familiarity or comfort with technology; higher values indicate greater familiarity
pol.info: Level of political information; higher values indicate more informed
white.collar: Occupation type (1 = white-collar, 0 = otherwise)
not.full.time: Employment status (1 = not full-time, 0 = full-time)
capable.auth: Poll worker qualification (1 = “quite” or “very qualified,” 0 otherwise)
eval.voting: Overall assessment of voting experience (1 = “very good,” 0 otherwise)
easy.voting: Ease of voting procedure (1 = “very easy,” 0 otherwise)
sure.counted: Confidence that vote was counted accurately (1 = “sure” or “very sure,” 0 otherwise)
conf.secret: Confidence in ballot secrecy (1 = “confident” or “very confident,” 0 otherwise)
how.clean: Perception of election cleanness (1 = “very” or “somewhat clean,” 0 otherwise)
speed: Speed of voting process (1 = “quick” or “very quick,” 0 otherwise)
agree.evoting: Support for substituting traditional voting with e-voting (1 = “agree” or “agree a lot,” 0 otherwise)
eselect.cand: Preference for selecting candidates (1 = electronically, 0 = by hand)
propensity_score: Estimated propensity score for analysis
natural_language_query: What is the effect of e-voting compared to traditional voting on voters' confidence in ballot secrecy?
